Dear Holly Anderton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not follow supervision procedure of a youth while at the
YMCA. Youth was in a locker room with two male youth. It's
unknown if anything occurred.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on May 13, 2024,
and reported they had no additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 15,
2024. Youth A reported she went to the YMCA on May 10, 2024, with
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Youth B. She reported when they got there, she
saw two male peers from school and hung out with them. Youth A
reported when she was in the hot tub area with these two male
peers, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Youth B were sitting there listening to the
conversation, which she noted was appropriate. Youth A reported
Youth B wanted to leave, so Staff 2 walked her upfront while Staff 1
stayed with Youth A. She reported after a bit of time she headed to
the family locker room to change and Staff 1 followed her. Youth A
reported in the family locker room there are single-stall rooms so she
could change in privacy and reported typically staff stand outside the
door until the youth comes out. She reported she went into the
single-stall room to change and Staff 1 was standing there when she
closed the door. Youth A reported Staff 1 knocked on the
door asking her if she was still in there which she responded she
was. She reported she thought that was strange that she was being
asked because Staff 1 would know if she left the room if she was
standing where staff are supposed to be. Youth A reported she does
not know if Staff 1 left the family restroom as she was changing. She
reported she came out of the room and left to go back to the facility
with Staff 1, Staff 2, and Youth B. Youth A reported she saw the two
male peers from her school when she was leaving the family locker
room and denied either of them were ever in the room with her
alone.
2

Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 15,
2024. Youth B reported she went to the YMCA with Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Youth A on May 10, 2024. Youth B reported, Youth A saw
friends from school and went into the pool with them. She reported
she walked to the front of the building with Staff 2 while Staff 1
stayed with Youth A. Youth B reported Staff 1 came out of the family
locker room without Youth A and came to check on Youth B. Youth B
reported Staff 1 had her back toward the glass area of the family
locker room where you could see the room Youth A was changing.
She reported Staff 2 told Staff 1 she needed to go back into the
family locker room to supervise Youth A and she told Staff 2 no.
Youth B reported after a couple of minutes, Staff 1 did go back into
the locker room to check on Youth A. She reported staff are
supposed to stand outside the door and wait for the youth to change
when in the family locker room. Youth B reported Staff 1 left Youth A
unsupervised for a period of time as she had her back to the door
Youth A was in. She reported at one point Staff 1 asked Youth B
where Youth A went because she was unsure if Youth A left the
locker room.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 15,
2024. Staff 1 reported she took Youth A and Youth B to the YMCA
with Staff 2 on May 10, 2024. She reported when she got there,
Youth A saw friends from school which is not abnormal, and Youth A
went into the hot tub with them. Staff 1 reported she, Youth B, and
Staff 2 sat next to the hot tub. Staff 1 reported Youth B walked to the
front of the YMCA with Staff 2. When Staff 2 was walking away, Staff
1 told him her cell phone was about to die so if he needed her to
have the facility page her on the overhead speaker. Staff 1 reported
she stayed with Youth A at the hot tub and then walked with her to
the family locker room when it was time for Youth A to change. She
reported after Youth A went into her single room; she went to the
front area to check in on Staff 2 because she was concerned about
Youth B’s mental health. Staff 1 reported she was able to see
the changing room door of the family locker room Youth A was in
through the glass and noted she could maintain supervision via
eyesight and not just standing near the door. She reported she
checked in with Youth B and Staff 2. Staff 1 reported at
one point Staff 2 told her she could not maintain supervision of Youth
A through the glass and noted that was in the supervision policy of
the facility. Staff 1 reported she thought Staff 2 was joking and
ignored the statement. She reported she went back into the family
locker room after about ten minutes and Youth A came out of the
single room. Staff 1 reported she thought she was doing the right
thing because her phone was dead, and she wanted to check in on
Youth B because she was concerned. She reported the family locker
room has two or three single stall changing rooms and you can see
the door to the rooms through the glass that surrounds the family
3

locker room. Staff 1 reported that she was unaware that it was
noted in policy that this could not be done and confirmed she has
been a part of all the supervision trainings at the facility. She reported
that the two male peers of Youth A’s did not enter the locker room
until the point of when Youth A was exiting the single stall. Staff 1
reported she does not believe Youth A was ever left alone with the
male peers.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 15,
2024. Staff 2 reported he took Youth A and Youth B with Staff 1 to
the YMCA on May 10, 2024. He reported when they got there, Youth
A saw two male peers from her school. Staff 2 reported Youth A
wanted to go to the hot tub with these two people, so Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Youth B went to sit by the hot tub. He reported Youth A was
redirected for touching one of the male peer’s backs. Staff 2 reported
Youth B wanted to leave so he brought her to the main entrance and
left Staff 1 with Youth A to supervise. Staff 2 reported he saw Staff 1
go into the family locker room with Youth A to change. He stated
moments later, Staff 1 walked out of the family locker room alone and
sat down with him and Youth B. Staff 2 reported he told Staff 1
several times that she needed to go back in the locker room, and she
kept dismissing him telling him that she can see the door through the
glass. He reported he told Staff 1 it is against the facility’s supervision
policy that staff cannot supervise through glass. Staff 2 reported at
one point Staff 1 made a comment when she was talking to Youth B
about where Youth A went. He reported after about seven minutes or
a bit more, Staff 1 went into the family locker room. Staff 2 reported
after a few minutes he saw Youth A walk out of the locker
room and the two male peers walked out of the family locker room a
minute after her. He reported he did not go into the family locker
room because he was sitting with Youth B who did not want to be
near Staff 1 and was on heightened supervision already. Staff 2
reported he also did not want to be in the family locker room alone
with a female youth when he is a male staff. He reported he spoke
with his Supervisor about the incident that occurred.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on May
15, 2024. Supervisor reported he was notified by Staff 2 that there
was a concern that Staff 1 lost supervision of Youth A at the YMCA.
He reported he gave the direction to Staff 2 to complete an incident
report. Supervisor reported when he read the incident report, he
became concerned that Youth A was left alone with two unknown
male peers. He reported he is the direct supervisor of Staff 1 and has
been working with her to make sure she is having professional
boundaries with the youth versus trying to be more of a friend with
them. Supervisor reported Staff 2 is more risk-averse to situations
and wants to make sure that everyone remains in a calm space. He
stated he would understand why she felt the need to check on Youth
4

B when she did not have a working phone but there should have
been a conversation between the two staff of what responsibility they
both had.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Supervision Policy with the revision date of July
2023- Policy notes under the section “Supervision of Youth
Using and Off-Campus Bathroom/Locker Room/Changing
Room”, that if a youth is in a private locker room, staff should
remain in a close proximity and maintain visual contact of the
door leading to the bathroom. Within both Staff 2 and Youth
B’s interview it was reported Staff 1 did not maintain visual
contact on Youth A’s locker room door. As it pertains to the
not allowing supervision through glass, the policy notes only
“Supervision of a youth outdoors cannot be accomplished
from a window or area inside a building regardless of whether
the staff member is able to maintain visual contact with the
youth form inside the building.” Youth A was not outside a
building when Staff 1 was maintaining supervision through
glass.
- Facility Incident Report dated May 10, 2024, completed by
Staff 2- This incident report is consistent with Staff 2’s
interview.
- Staff 1’s Human Resource File- Staff 1 was given a verbal
warning and placed on a corrective action and improvement
plan at the facility on April 29, 2024, due to Staff 1 discussing
sexual behavior with a youth at a store in the community on
April 25, 2024. Staff 1 has had increased supervision,
additional training and monthly video review on her shifts she
works. Staff 1 is in compliance with all her required trainings
and completed her most recent supervision policy training on
November 13, 2023.
- Staff 2’s Human Resource File- Staff 2 has two disciplinary
actions noted within his file due to medication error and
attendance/tardiness. Staff 2 is in compliance with all his
required trainings and completed his most recent supervision
policy training on November 13, 2023.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, Staff 1 did not follow the facility’s supervision policy as
it was noted Staff 1 did not maintain visual contact of Youth A’s
locker room door while at the YMCA.
Technical Assistance
Technical Assistance was offered for the facility to review the
internal supervision policy regarding staff supervising through
5

glass. The policy reads that staff should not supervise through
glass when a youth is outside. Staff 2 had the understanding that
supervision through glass at any time is unacceptable.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
